glossary.definition: An electrical circuit that performs logical operations on binary inputs to produce a binary output.
A numeral system that uses only two digits, 0 and 1, as the foundation of digital electronics and computing systems.
A branch of algebra that deals with binary variables and logical operations, forming the theoretical foundation for logic circuits.
A basic building block of logic circuits that performs a simple logical function such as AND, OR, NOT, NAND, NOR, XOR, or XNOR.
A logic gate that produces a true (1) output only if all its inputs are true.
A logic gate that produces a true (1) output if at least one of its inputs is true.
A logic gate that inverts its input signal; true becomes false, and false becomes true.
A logic gate that produces a false (0) output only if all its inputs are true, which is the negation of the AND gate.
A logic gate that produces a true (1) output only when all its inputs are false.
A logic gate that produces a true (1) output only when the number of true inputs is odd.
A logic gate that produces a true (1) output only when the number of true inputs is even.
A table used to represent the logical relationship between inputs and outputs of a logic gate or circuit.
A type of logic circuit where the output is determined solely by the current inputs.
A type of logic circuit where the output depends on both current inputs and previous states, often using memory elements like flip-flops.
A digital memory circuit that can hold one bit of information, used in sequential circuits.
